SEARCH
Module org.klojang.jdbc
Package org.klojang.jdbc

Interface BindInfo

public interface BindInfo
BindInfo objects allow you to determine how values are bound into a PreparedStatement. Ordinarily Klojang JDBC will have enough context to figure this out automatically. However, if you want or need to, this interface enables you to override the default behaviour. You might want to implement BindInfo through an anonymous class: 

 BindInfo bindInfo = new BindInfo() {
   public boolean saveEnumAsString(Class<?> beanType, String enumProperty) {
     return true;
   }
 };
Author:
Ayco Holleman

    Field

    static final BindInfo
    DEFAULT
    A BindInfo that does not override the default binding behaviour.

  • Field Details

    • DEFAULT

      static final BindInfo DEFAULT

  • Method Details

    • getSqlType

      default Integer getSqlType(Class<?> javaType, Class<?> containerType, String name)
      Specifies the storage type (the SQL datatype) for a value. The return value must either be one of the constants in the java.sql.Types class (like Types.VARCHAR) or null. Returning null means you leave it to Klojang JDBC to figure out the SQL datatype. The default implementation returns null. You may ignore any argument that you don't need in order to determine the SQL datatype. For example, in many cases the type of the value is all you need to know in order to determine the corresponding SQL datatype.
      Parameters:
      javaType - the type of the value whose SQL datatype to determine
      containerType - the class containing the value. May be a JavaBean type, a record type, or the type of the Map being bound using SQLStatement.bind(Map). In the latter case, it will always be the concrete type of the Map (e.g. HashMap.class) — never Map.class itself.
      name - the name of the bean property, record component, or map key for which to specify the SQL datatype.
      Returns:
      one of the class constants of the java.sql.Types class or null

    • saveEnumAsString

      default boolean saveEnumAsString(Class<?> containerType, String name)
      Whether to save enums as strings (by calling their toString() method) or as ints (by calling their ordinal() method). The default implementation return false, meaning that by default Klojang JDBC will save enums as ints. More precisely: Klojang JDBC will bind enum types using preparedStatement.setInt(myEnum.ordinal()). You can ignore any argument that you don't need in order to determine the storage type. To save all enums in your application as strings, simply return true straight away.
      Parameters:
      containerType - the class containing the enum value. May be a JavaBean type, a record type, or the type of the Map being bound using SQLStatement.bind(Map). In the latter case, it will always be the concrete type of the Map (e.g. HashMap.class) — never Map.class itself.
      name - the name of the bean property, record component, or map key for which to specify the SQL datatype.
      Returns:
      whether to bind enums as strings (true) or as ints (false)
